articles.headline: Ex-Chief of A.I.G. Settles S.E.C. Case for $15 Million
articles.snippet: Maurice R. Greenberg was accused of overseeing deals that fraudulently overstated A.I.G.’s financial position.
articles.abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg was accused of overseeing deals that fraudulently overstated A.I.G.’s financial position.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators announced an agreement with Maurice R. Greenberg on Thursday to settle accusations that he oversaw an accounting fraud at the American International Group.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Sotomayor Confirmed by Senate, 68-31
articles.snippet: Democrats celebrated the relatively smooth confirmation process for Sonia Sotomayor, even as most Senate Republicans voted against her.
articles.abstract: Democrats celebrated the relatively smooth confirmation process for Sonia Sotomayor, even as most Senate Republicans voted against her.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday confirmed Judge Sonia Sotomayor as the nation’s first Hispanic Supreme Court justice, concluding a 10-week battle with a resounding victory for the White House.

articles.headline: Inside G.E., a Little Bit of Enron
articles.snippet: Fiddling with the books to make earnings forecasts, side deals to inflate profits.... Where have we heard this before?
articles.abstract: Fiddling with the books to make earnings forecasts, side deals to inflate profits.... Where have we heard this before?
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, General Electric was the shining star of American business. Its longtime chief executive, Jack Welch, was named manager of the century by Fortune Magazine, and its stock seemed always to go up.

articles.headline: Iraqis Freed by U.S. Face Few Jobs and Little Hope
articles.snippet: A grim welcome awaits many ex-detainees, who often are recruited by insurgents or suspected of spying for the U.S.
articles.abstract: A grim welcome awaits many ex-detainees, who often are recruited by insurgents or suspected of spying for the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  One day in early February, after a year and a half in various American detention centers, detainee No. 318360 was handed a letter that he was to give to his mother.

articles.headline: Citigroup Considers Changes at Phibro
articles.snippet: Citigroup may be considering a deal that would give control of its Phibro commodities business to Andrew J. Hall, whose nine-figure salary has become a political hot potato.
articles.abstract: Citigroup may be considering a deal that would give control of its Phibro commodities business to Andrew J. Hall, whose nine-figure salary has become a political hot potato.
articles.lead_paragraph: Will Citigroup turn loose its $100 million man, Andrew J. Hall?

articles.headline: Another Hurdle for the Jobless: Credit Inquiries
articles.snippet: Some states have passed laws requiring prospective employers to show credit checks have relevance to the nature of the job.
articles.abstract: Some states have passed laws requiring prospective employers to show credit checks have relevance to the nature of the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: Digging out of debt keeps getting harder for the unemployed as more companies use detailed credit checks to screen job prospects.

articles.headline: Governors Fear Added Costs in Health Care Overhaul
articles.snippet: Some worry that Congress will give the states expensive new Medicaid obligations without providing enough new money to pay for them.
articles.abstract: Some worry that Congress will give the states expensive new Medicaid obligations without providing enough new money to pay for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  The fraying of the nation’s Medicaid system has many indicators, and one of them is Connie Baugh’s stockings.

articles.headline: Economists See a Limited Boost From Stimulus
articles.snippet: Economists say that the punch from increased government spending has helped the economy begin to bottom out faster than it would have otherwise.
articles.abstract: Economists say that the punch from increased government spending has helped the economy begin to bottom out faster than it would have otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Even as the Obama administration braces for another grim report about job losses on Friday, economists say that the president’s $787 billion stimulus package has helped blunt the downturn in limited but discernible ways.

articles.headline: With High-Profile Death, Focus on High-Risk Drug
articles.snippet: Michael Jackson’s death has brought a new spotlight to the anesthetic propofol, which experts say is being abused.
articles.abstract: Michael Jackson’s death has brought a new spotlight to the anesthetic propofol, which experts say is being abused.
articles.lead_paragraph: As an anesthesiologist in a Nebraska hospital, he administered it to patients daily  propofol, a drug used to sedate millions of patients before surgery.

articles.headline: Taliban Leader in Pakistan Is Reportedly Killed
articles.snippet: Baitullah Mehsud was blamed for the assassination of Benazir Bhutto and scores of suicide bombings.
articles.abstract: Baitullah Mehsud was blamed for the assassination of Benazir Bhutto and scores of suicide bombings.
articles.lead_paragraph: By Pir Zubair Shah, Sabrina Tavernise and Mark Mazzetti
articles.byline: By Pir Zubair Shah, Sabrina Tavernise and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Job Losses Slow, Signaling Momentum for a Recovery
articles.snippet: The most heartening employment report since last summer suggested on Friday that a recovery is under way despite the reluctance of the nation’s businesses to resume hiring or even stop shedding jobs.
articles.abstract: The most heartening employment report since last summer suggested on Friday that a recovery is under way despite the reluctance of the nation’s businesses to resume hiring or even stop shedding jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most heartening employment report since last summer suggested on Friday that a recovery was under way  and perhaps gathering steam  despite the reluctance of the nation’s businesses to resume hiring or even stop shedding jobs.
articles.byline: By Louis Uchitelle and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Good Luck Getting Private Insurance for Unemployment
articles.snippet: Paycheck replacement coverage is scarce, if it exists at all.
articles.abstract: Paycheck replacement coverage is scarce, if it exists at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest figures from the Department of Labor show that 247,000 more jobs disappeared last month. And right about now, many of the people who had those jobs probably wish they had something more coming to them than some severance pay and a small check from the state unemployment department.
